Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{At}x \\), where \\( A \\) is a constant, complex matrix, and \\( x \\) is a vector in \\( \\mathbb{C}^n \\). We analyze how the function \\( f(z) = \\int_0^t e^{B\\tau}z(\\tau) d\\tau \\), with \\( B \\) also a constant matrix, changes the evolution of \\( z(t) \\) over time.

If \\( f(z) \\) is computed at \\( t = 0 \\) and then \\( z(t) \\) evolves by \\( z(t) = e^{At}x \\) for \\( t > 0 \\) without further application of \\( f \\), will the state at \\( t = T \\) be the same as if \\( f \\) was never applied?
Explanation: Since \\( f(z) \\) at \\( t = 0 \\) is simply the zero vector (due to the integral of zero), the subsequent evolution of \\( z(t) \\) remains unaltered. Therefore, it follows the prescribed exponential map \\( e^{At}x \\), resulting in the same state at any \\( t = T \\) as if the transformation was never applied.
